nova/virt/driver.py.message: Why can't we just use instance.numa_topology? Or is that not the 'claimed' numa topology?

Yeah, the claimed numa topology might be different because of the different fit on the dest.

And actually this makes me realize that we're not actually saving the new instance NUMA topology after the live migration - dropping the claim and the migration context cleans up resources, but I don't see them updating the instance object anywhere. So I'll have to add that to the final patch.

I don't think I see why we need to make this part of the formal interface for everyone here. It matters to libvirt, which is going to use it to make the returned migrate_data.

In compute manager's check_can_live_migrate_destination(), we call this check for the driver, and then call straight to the source.

Wouldn't it be cleaner to have the source return the numa_topology (since it's clearly in the same cell as the instance, and knows about the instance)? Then if we need to call to another check in the driver after receiving the info from the source, we could do that from compute manager, passing the updated migrate_data that the source has augmented, etc.

That would mean instead of modifying every driver to take this parameter it doesn't support, we add one new method to the driver base class, which is a no-op for everything that doesn't need to re-check after the source's pre-check was completed.

Also, I think that if you can decouple the claim from the destination check, your upgrade problem gets a lot easier. If you wait to claim until after you know if the source is going to do the right thing, you can avoid the error-prone checking in this very first step to determine whether or not you should do a claim which you might not be able to finish. Going to another driver call after the source-side check seems like that would solve several problems to me.

> Also, I think that if you can decouple the claim from the
 > destination check

I don't think we can. The claim could fail if the instance doesn't fit, at which point we need to reject that destination.

 > your upgrade problem gets a lot easier. If you
 > wait to claim until after you know if the source is going to do the
 > right thing, you can avoid the error-prone checking in this very
 > first step to determine whether or not you should do a claim which
 > you might not be able to finish. Going to another driver call after
 > the source-side check seems like that would solve several problems
 > to me.

Okay, so numa_topology comes from the claim on the dest I guess, even though it's entirely calculated from the instance_type (and host state I assume). So I assume you're doing things in the order you are just because of where the claim is and when you've got the numa_topology that came from it. That seems like some unfortunately deep-coupling of multiple services which can be running at different versions, so I think it would be good if we could try to avoid that.

As I said on the other line, since with version 5.2 migration isn't optional, I'd rather update the unit tests and not default this to None.

You'll need to keep in mind for whatever relies on this later that if this is an old compute it won't have this parameter. I assume it will be check_can_live_migrate_source which will be checking the contents of dest_check_data and if this dest host is old, the dest_check_data just won't have whatever data you're looking for on the source side. Which also means we likely need to have a minimum compute service version check somewhere before we enable numa live migration (I guess we'd do that service version check in conductor).

Yeah but you can have source computes that are running Rocky code and won't have that check. Which is why something (probably conductor) is still going to have to make sure both the source and dest are new enough to support this new behavior for numa live migration.
If a new conductor calls this wouldn't the migration param get backeleveled out of the call by the rpcapi layer?

Yes. My point is just that the source compute can't assume it's going to get the data from an older dest compute. If the source does require it coming over the wire from the dest, then we need a higher level service version check on *both* compute services which is where conductor would do that.

So in the spec we talked about not blocking live migration for old computes because live migrating workloads during rolling upgrades is a common use case. We even made a truth table [1] :)

So what I'm doing in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634606/29/nova/compute/manager.py is checking the source or dest compute version at every step. That way you could live migrate from an old compute to a new compute. You wouldn't get the new claims and updated XML, but it would at least work assuming you know what you're doing and have, for example, provided an identical, empty new dest compute.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/stein/approved/numa-aware-live-migration.html#upgrade-impact

On the source it's handled by just checking for the presence of `dst_numa_config` in the migrate_data:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/635229/20/nova/virt/libvirt/migration.py@92
we should have a default value None for it. When the cluster is under the upgrade, we will pin the rpc call to the lower version, that means we won't pass a value for this parameter.
Good point. Even new conductor + new compute will be missing `migration` if the deployment is in the middle of an upgrade and is pinned to the old RPC version. Done.
Just piling on here, but.. yep, all arguments past N.0 need to be defaulted. The RPC layer actually calls these by kwarg.

You don't seem to be using either of these here, which means you shouldn't be changing the definition and updating the version. If you do this kind of thing, we can't differentiate between a service that requires a thing, and a service that uses that required thing.
Squashed into the top patch, so we're now using them in the same patch.
Squashed into the top patch.

You didn't add this to the docstring. Also same issue as above...adding this as required/accepted before you use it is violating the versioning contract. You claim to support 5.2 if you take this, but...then you don't do what 5.2 says you do.
Done (and squashed).

It's purely for completeness' sake. We don't _need_ to enable the filter just as no one _needs_ to enable the NUMATopologyFilter in general. However, by not doing it, the scheduler won't be able to do any of the additional sanity checks to ensure you'll be able to fit on the host meaning you'll increase the chances of late stage build failures resulting from landing on compute nodes that e.g. don't have enough hugepages. That doesn't really affect us here, but I'm thinking that since it's not realistic for someone to be using real-time features without this filter enabled, this filter should be enabled here since functional tests should try to mimic real-world behavior.

doc/source/user/dynamic-emulator.rst.message: I would highly prefer that we don't try to create a storage pool unless we're basically offering up swordfish compatability. Maybe that is the goal, but doing it for the user makes this a little too easy to layer into other things outside of CI/testing use cases.

The idea is to simplify emulator use by not requiring the user to prepare libvirt for simple storage emulation. The alternative is to document the necessary steps and leave it alone.

@TheJuila in the context of this patch, we are not doing anything Swordfish. 

Storage pool mentioned here belongs to libvirt. In this patch we emulate Redfish simple storage based on libvirt volume, which resides within libvirt storage pool.

I may have misread your comment, though...

The volume_creation step in the Volumes emulation will also require us to attach the new volume to a domain/VM for usability in Simple Storage because here we are examining the xml desc of the domain and only attaching a volume will make the volume appear in the domain.

Now, there is one problem with attaching a volume automatically, we will also need to supply the target bus value for attaching the volume which can take values like 'ide'/'virtio'/'scsi' that we are using in Simple Storage along with a unique device that has not been previously used by another volume such as 'sda/sdb/sdc' for 'scsi' bus type, 'hda/hdb/hdc' for 'ide' bus type and 'vda/vdb/vdc' for 'virtio' bus type. 

So, while attaching a disk, do I just attach every new volume with a single bus type such as 'virtio' or pick an arbitrary bus type from the above three and attach accordingly?
Works for me!

I think what I can do is state that the user needs to create a volume via `create_volume` or a regular storage if he wants to see any devices for the Simple Storage and will take care of the create_volume in the Volumes emulation patch.

We are not persisting requested_resources, as the final truth is outside of nova regarding port of cyborg device resource requests. 

So when we start a migrate operation we collect every request again. So I don't think we ever want to implement a merge behavior here. What we want is the following pseudo code:

   # other non nova managed resources...

   self.request_spec.requested_resources = net_resources + accel_resources # + other_non_nova_resources...

container_config_scripts/pacemaker_resta.message: nit: not sequentially though, no? in parallel on all nodes (within the step/task that does it)
yeah you're right, i meant "in parallel on all nodes, for each deploy step". I'll reword this

I get the rest of the xml (very clever, kudos!). not sure I fully grasp the target_role boolean stuff here. Mind adding a comment so our old selves won't need to spend too much time retracing the logic?

The idea is that resource have a current state and a target state (i.e. the target-role in pcs). Until the resource reached the target state, a transient attribute is present in the crm.

I wanted to prevent restarting the resource if its transient state is "Stopped" (i.e. something did a pcs resource disable <resource>), to prevent any unexpected side effect in pacemaker.

So the XPath reads "either there's no transient state, or if there is it has to be something different than Stopped".

setup.cfg.message: There is already an aggregate top level key in the openstack CLI provided by nova to manipulate host aggregates. This new command now added to the same top level key but it manipulates placement aggregates if I understand correctly. Mixing these two entities under the same name could be confusing to the CLI user. The placement aggregate handling commands are under 'resource provider aggregate' path.

Yeah, I did it this way because this is a batch command that operates upon multiple resource providers in a single aggregate, whereas the 'resource provider aggregate' commands operate upon a single resource provider UUID. I thought it might be confusing to have a batch command under 'resource provider aggregate'. But I'm fine to change it to whatever the consensus wants.

Note to reviewers: I chose to make a new command instead of re-using 'set' because 'set' requires the user to supply an entire replacement of inventory when called, which didn't seem friendly for a batch command (all resource providers assumed to have identical existing inventory?).

'update' is also useful in general I think, to let users be able to request updates without having to do full replacements, and let the CLI handle the GET, update, PUT for them.

nova/virt/libvirt/config.py.message: I think you also need a parse_dom() here.

ICBW but this doesn't look consistent with the rest of config.py.  The existing design is described in a docstring at the top:

> Classes to represent the configuration of various libvirt objects and support conversion to/from XML. These classes are solely concerned by providing direct Object <-> XML document conversions. No policy or operational decisions should be made by code in these classes. Such policy belongs in the 'designer.py' module which provides simplified helpers for populating up config object instances.

So decisions such as "we need to make sure every device is virtio" belong in the driver, not here.

IIUC this is why every LibvirtConfig* class in config.py corresponds to a chunk of XML, handles the parsing of XML via parse_dom(), and the generation of XML via format_dom().  Consequently they all inherit from LibvirtConfigObject, and all have a "root_name".
I don't think this is necessary here since it's not parsing or generating XML.  Later we can add logic to driver.py which sets the hard limit correctly in the SEV case.
Again this is operational logic which IIUC doesn't belong in this class.  We can add it to driver.py later.
I don't think there is anywhere natural we could introduce a caller of this method from within the existing design of the code.

Based on my above comment, I think LibvirtConfigGuestSEVLaunchSecurity should be consumed by LibvirtConfigGuest, since <launchSecurity> is a top-level element under <domain>.  That goes for both LibvirtConfigGuestSEVLaunchSecurity.format_dom() and LibvirtConfigGuestSEVLaunchSecurity.parse_dom() (which is currently missing).

No, I think that's wrong.  It's clearly stated at the top of config.py that it should not make any policy decisions:

    """

1) Prefer parens to backslash

2) We should (again) consider what happens if both the flavor and the image specify the key, but with conflicting values. Specifically:

- If the admin (via the flavor) explicitly said False, is it okay for the user (via the image) to override that by saying True? Thereby consuming a potentially precious resource (a MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT) and hiding his guest's memory from the admin who might have wanted the ability to snoop it (hey, stranger things have happened).
- If the admin explicitly said True, is it okay for the user to say False? Thereby allowing snooping of the guest's memory when the admin didn't want that.

Correct answer in both cases: no.

So if that happens, do we a) log a warning and give the flavor precedence, or b) raise an exception and refuse to continue?

In this case, since we're talking about security stuff, I say b), fail hard and fast.

> 1) Prefer parens to backslash

Done.

 > 2) We should (again) consider what happens if both the flavor and the image specify the key, but with conflicting values.

Excellent point which hadn't ever occurred to me!

 > Specifically:
 > 
 > - If the admin (via the flavor) explicitly said False, is it okay for the user (via the image) to override that by saying True? Thereby consuming a potentially precious resource (a MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT) and hiding his guest's memory from the admin who might have wanted the ability to snoop it (hey, stranger things have happened).

If the flavor explicitly said hw:mem_encryption=False, the user could probably just pick another flavor.  And it seems very unlikely that every flavor would explicitly have False; if the admin wanted to prevent usage of SEV, they would just set num_memory_encrypted_guests to 0, or configure the kernel parameter to 0, or (much less sensibly) run a version of QEMU/libvirt/nova which didn't support it, or one of several other options.

 > - If the admin explicitly said True, is it okay for the user to say False? Thereby allowing snooping of the guest's memory when the admin didn't want that.

Well, again flavor characteristics aren't purely the choice of the admin, because the user chooses which flavor to use.  And it's hard to imagine a scenarios where the admin wants to force all instances to have encrypted memory, because encrypted memory is intended for the benefit of the user, protecting them against a malicious admin rather than vice versa.  One could maybe make the argument that an admin might want all instances to be encrypted so that the user can't ever accuse the admin of violating their privacy by prying into guest memory contents, but I'm not sure that the attestation process would allow the admin to prove that they couldn't have engaged in such privacy violations, since it's designed to allow the *user* to prove that.

 > Correct answer in both cases: no.

I don't necessarily disagree, but I'm not sure it's quite as cut and dried as you portray.

 > So if that happens, do we a) log a warning and give the flavor precedence, or b) raise an exception and refuse to continue?
 > 
 > In this case, since we're talking about security stuff, I say b), fail hard and fast.

I'm fine with that and I've implemented it in the next patch set, but I think this warrants a bit more research (a.k.a. asking my AMD / SUSE contacts) how they envisage these use cases working out.  I've just been on a conf call with AMD and their initial reaction to this scenario is to agree with your suggestion of bailing when there's a conflict regarding what has been requested.

mmph, I have a couple of problems with this.

I first came across the method name "mem_encryption_requestors" and assumed it was going to return something like (True, False) or {'flavor': True, 'image': False} or...

Then I saw how the result was being used in the request filter (boolean-ish) and was like wha...? But I didn't yet notice how it was being used in the log.

It wasn't until I got to the implementation that I realized the semantic is:
- Return a list of zero, one, or two strings
- If the list is empty, don't do mem encryption
- Otherwise, do memory encryption, and the list can be used to construct a message, but you have to know exactly how that message needs to be put together.

That seems really odd, and tightly coupled to the consuming code.

My second issue is the way message construction is being done. It's generally a no-no to put otherwise-translatable words/phrases into format vars, because a) they don't get translated, so the message winds up being a mix of English and $language; and b) assuming the injected text is comprehensible to the reader, the whole may not make any sense due to differences in sentence structure etc.

Now, in this case, we're only using the result for a debug log, which isn't translated, so the second point is moot... until some other consumer decides to use it for an exception, or we decide to start translating logs again, or...

I'm not going to block on the second thing. But I am going to downvote on the tight coupling and general ickiness.

I would prefer if this method returned ($bool, $bool) indicating whether memory encryption was requested by the (flavor, image) -- described explicitly in the docstring. The caller can do the switch-on logic with any(); and then can do all the message assembly locally.

I had a better idea in my sleep last night:

Let's make this method mem_encryption_requested, and have it return a single boolean (or raise), and have it do the logging itself.

The request filter can tack on another log just saying "requesting mem encryption" which, in the context of the other logs, is all that's necessary.
Done

Understood, but this feels like we're reducing the discussion down to "small functions are good and big functions are bad", which is of course a huge oversimplification. I've clearly got many years less professional experience (a mere 6) but things like coupling vs. cohesion and cyclomatic complexity are fortunately taught from the get go and in my opinion splitting things up like we're doing here reduces the cohesiveness/readability of the function and does extremely little w.r.t. reducing something like cyclomatic complexity.

Put it this way: if I were to insert a couple of functions between this function and the one above, such that they ended up on different pages, would you find this implementation as easy to grok as if they were merged? I don't think it would (otherwise I wouldn't ask the question :)) and, more importantly, I don't think the costs of merging things together _in this instance_ outweigh the impact on grokability that splitting them out does.

For me RequestSpec is intended to driver the scheduling of the instance. See requested_destination, retry fields. Those for me does not belong to the instance itself.

There are also quirks around instance multi-create.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/type_vlan.py.message:
in the commit msg you mentioned check for 0....
Anyway "if segmentation_id:..." EQUALS with "if segmentation_id is not None:...."

Anyway 2: the validation code is here: https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/src/branch/master/neutron_lib/plugins/utils.py#L49

Hi Lajos, Thanks for your comments firstly.
Yes, the vlan validation code is is_valid_vlan_tag, 
but if 0 is the segmentation id, The condition (if segmentation_id) is false, the network with 0 segmentation id could create successfully, this is not right.
however, This condition (if segmentation_id is not None) is true, it will execute is_valid_vlan_tag check if the segmentation id is illegal, it can throw the exception correctly
sounds a great idea, Done, could you take a look what's wrong with the testing result? I really don't know where is the problem after looked into it several times.

Hi Frank,
I think I see now your problem. 
Please consider this suggestion, I see it more pythonic:
if segmentation_id and int(segmentation_id) >= 0:
    .....

After checking in details, this was not that good idea, as first the if segmentation_id part is checked by the interpreter, and if segmentation_id is 0 (or None).
So I think the best (my opinion) would be:

1) Your original solution (sorry for causing trouble): 
if segmentation_id is not None:
    ....
As the is_valid_vlan_tag method anyway checks if the segm_id is int, you can trust in it I suppose.

2) A longer version that checks the type of segm_id
if isinstance(segmentation_id, int) and segmentation_is >=0:
     .....

I can't vouch for the correctness or efficiency or maintainability or even style of this code, but it does look similar to the code for subnets, which I guess was based on the original code for networks. If it was cut-and-pasted, where any substantive changes made?

I'm OK with this for now (assuming it works) but would really like to eventually simplify how these bulk functions are implemented, and we can do that for all resources later.

The related resources are different. For router we only care about contract and subject DN. But I think everything after line#1668 (starting with # Merge statuses) should be the same across network, subnet and router. I can do a quick follow-up patch to refactor this a bit right after this patch goes in then.

nova/tests/live_migration/hooks/run_test.message:
Will this actually test cold migration or just resize?

A couple other things here:

1. This script runs some tests with a default devstack configuration which is local disk and lvm volumes and does block migration, then re-configures the environment for ceph and tests using shared storage, but you've only hit the latter. So if we want to test the former for cold migration and resize as well, you need to run this earlier before we re-configure for ceph.

2. This script is also used by the nova-live-migration job, so simply adding this here but leaving the nova-live-migration job with that name when it runs more than live migration (actually that job already runs more than live migration, it also runs evacuate testing [1]), is a bit confusing. So for now, I think we should somehow make this conditional to only run for the grenade job until/unless we rename the nova-live-migration job to nova-multinode later. I think you can do that by inspecting if there is a grenade environment variable defined, like GRENADE_PHASE [2].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/912a46c9d4d3a8cc63724adff70acf8a4fc34d9b/playbooks/legacy/nova-live-migration/run.yaml#L52
[2] https://ac13160b9f6505cb4f48-58ad23e4ce64c146e6acb1a522568306.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/663851/42/check/nova-grenade-live-migration/ef84274/logs/old/local_conf.txt.gz
